description:
'''New jack swing''', '''new jack''', or '''swingbeat''' is a [[Fusion (music)|fusion genre]] of the rhythms and [[music production|production]] techniques of [[Hip hop music|hip hop]] and [[dance-pop]], and the [[urban contemporary]] sound of [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]]. Spearheaded by producers [[Teddy Riley]], [[Bernard Belle]], [[Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis]], [[Dallas Austin]], new jack swing was most popular from the late 1980s to early 1990s.

New jack swing can be defined as "pop music usually performed by [[African-American music|black musicians]] that combines elements of [[jazz]], [[funk]], [[Rapping|rap]], and [[rhythm and blues]]." New jack swing producers created [[Synthesizer|synthesized]] tunes and [[Sampling (music)|sampled]] beats, using [[digital synthesizers]] (such as the [[Yamaha DX7]] and [[Roland D50]]), [[drum machines]] (such as the [[Roland TR-808]]) and [[Sampler (musical instrument)|samplers]] (such as the [[SP-1200]] and [[Akai]] samplers), to lay an "insistent beat under light melody lines and clearly enunciated vocals." The TR-808 in particular was sampled to create distinctive, syncopated, [[Swing (jazz performance style)|swung]] rhythms, with its snare sound being especially prominent.
